CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, February 22, 1947, pg. 3, reads: "First Passenger - King Cole, whose trio played a two-day engagement at the Rankin Sports Arena this week, was the first customer of the new Owl Cab Company Wednesday afternoon. Pictured with him is Miss Marie [Maria] Ellington, sitting in the cab. The uniformed driver is Leo Dodson. The Owl Cab Company began service following a parade of all cabs through the Hill District and downtown areas Wednesday morning. - Harris Photo."Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, national edition, March 1, 1947, pg. 11, reads: "Break Cab Monopoly - The stranglehold held by the Yellow Cab Company in Pittsburgh, Pa., was broken last week when the Owl Cab Company put a fleet of fifteen cabs on the streets, with another twenty-five vehicles on order. For years, Smoky City residents had complained of shortcomings in transportation system of cabs, with only the Yellow Cab firm having a franchise to operate. However, State officials in Harrisburg, Pa., granted the Owl Cab Company a franchise, and the new firm, headed by Silas P. Knox, formerly of St. Louis, immediately went into action. Pittsburghers, white and colored, hailed the new cabs and their natty drivers, and the first day's business was a sell-out for President Knox and his all-colored firm. The Courier cameraman followed the Owls through on the first day, and here is their panorama: Left: Nat (King) Cole becomes the first Owl passenger, as he boards a cab in the Hill District... - Courier Photos by Moss and Harris"
TitMainTitle: Nat King Cole and Maria Cole with Owl Cab driver Leo Dodson, Hill District
